_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This document and the accompanying spreadsheet contain all required information in order to meet 40 CFR 68 "Risk Management Program" (RMP) including an Executive Summary and RMP data elements (68.155 through 68.185).

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.0 Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The Holland Energy LLC Power Generation facility in Beecher City, Illinois is a brand new facility which uses the latest in equipment and technology to improve safety, thereby preventing releases of anhydrous* ammonia.  For example, this facility is implementing an electronic preventive maintenance system.  This is a system that uses a real time database to track inspection dates and issue reminders to responsible groups.  Training is tracked on an internal spreadsheet.

The emergency response policies at the Holland Energy facility ensure that there is emergency response coverage 24 hours - 7 days per week.  There are also adequate provisions for coordination with outside agencies such as with the Beecher City Volunteer Fire Department in the event of an emergency.

*From this point in the Executive Summary, anhydrous ammonia will be synonymous with ammonia.

2.0 Process Description and Regulated Substances

The Holland Energy facility is currently under construction and will be a 650 MW Combined Cycle Power Plant located in Shelby County, Illinois.  This is one of the new merchant power projects being developed in the Midwest.

The design of the facility incorporates a 2-on-1 configuration, 650 MW (nominal) combined cycle plant that includes two single-fuel combustion turbine generators (CTG's), each linked to a supplementary-fired heat recovery steam generator (HRSG), producing steam to drive one common condensing steam turbine generator (STG).  The plant is designed to operate in base or peaking load conditions with natural gas as the primary fuel.  Currently, no back up fuels are planned.

The project site is located in Holland Township, Shelby County, Illinois directly nor

th of the Shelby and Effingham County lines. The North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) code for the primary process at this facility is 221112.  The facility is capable of producing power that is then distributed.  Anhydrous Ammonia is stored on-site to provide ammonia vapor to control NOx emissions at each of the facilities two (2) heat recovery steam generator stacks.

The Holland Energy plant has one regulated substance under 40 CFR 68: ammonia.  Ammonia is used to control NOx in the steam generator stacks (DENOx System).

The ammonia threshold for triggering applicability to 40 CFR 68 is 10,000 pounds. The quantity of ammonia stored on-site is 54,350 pounds with administrative controls.  Thus, 40 CFR 68 is applicable to the Holland Energy facility in Beecher City, IL.

3.0 Worst-case and Alternative Release Scenarios

The ammonia storage tank has associated hazards that can potentially affect on-site employees and the general public if there is a release from the system. Although the alternative release scenario is more probable, the US EPA requires that one worst-case and one alternative release scenario is reported for each regulated chemical. Described below are the associated hazards and the worst-case and alternative release scenarios for each regulated chemical.                                                                                                                            

Ammonia

Ammonia is classified as a Group 2 Refrigerant per ASHRAE Standard 34-1989.  The dominant characteristic of this chemical is its toxicity.  It is a self-alarming chemical by its distinctive pungent odor.  Due to this odor, persons exposed to ammonia vapor will not voluntarily stay in areas of even small concentrations.  Ammonia is flammable in a very narrow and high range of concentration with a high ignition temperature.  It is not poisonous, but it is corrosive to human tissue.  Ammonia is readily absorbed into the moisture of the skin and, at high

concentrations, can cause severe burns.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             The risks to persons in an accidental release of ammonia include:

1. Irritation of respiratory tract,
2. Corrosive attack of skin and other tissue,
3. Freezing of skin and other body tissue when contacted by liquid ammonia.

Although there are quality and safety systems in place at Holland Energy's Beecher City plant, the ammonia DENOx system has associated hazards that can potentially affect on-site employees and the general public if there is a release from the system. Although the alternative release scenario is more probable, the US EPA requires that one worst-case and one alternative release scenario is reported for each regulated chemical.  Given the safety precautions at the plant, both scenarios are unlikely to occur.

The ammonia release scenarios were modeled using EPA's RMP*COMP to obtain the distance to
endpoint.  The endpoint, as defined by the US EPA, is the Emergency Response Planning Guideline,
Level - 2 (ERPG-2).  The ERPG-2 was developed by the American Industrial Hygiene Association and is applicable to human exposures for up to one hour.  The ERPG-2 is intended to protect individuals from health threatening or escape impairing injury and is not generally considered fatal.

7.0 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Based on the Process Hazard Analysis (what-if PHA) completed for ammonia, a list of action items were developed and are being monitored to determine if implementation will be accomplished.  For example, in the event of an ammonia system leak, an emergency action plan has been developed. The preventive maintenance program addresses scheduled maintenance for fittings, piping, pressure relief valves or other instrumentation. There are numerous other examples of safety improvements that will result from the PHA.  These include:

1. Fully developed Emergency Action Plan. (Implemented, May 2002)

2. Accurate labeling of valves and piping. (To be implemented in 2002)

3. Written Operating Procedures. (Implemented, May 2002)

4. Preventive Maintenance Procedures. (Implemented, May 2002)

5. Installation of a ladder as a means of egress in and out of the dike. (To be implemented in 2002)
